'Documentation and Transformation' Yale University Art Gallery 1111 Chapel Street, at York Street New Haven Through Sunday

''Imaging African Art'' is a display of 43 works, mostly photographic. It deals with the ways Americans, black and white, have responded to the African diaspora. Early photographs of African sculpture by Charles Sheeler and Walker Evans show its influence on European Modernism, while painting and printmaking were the mediums used by Wilmer Jennings and Lois Maillou Jones in the 1930's to reach back to their African heritage.

Romare Bearden evokes the meld of European and African cultural influences on the lives of black Americans in a 1964 collage. Among present-day contributions, Carrie Mae Weems documents in photographs the dungeons on Africa's West Coast where blacks were rounded up to be shipped abroad as slaves. A bit of a hodgepodge, ''Imaging African Art'' is more interesting as a collection of distinctive works than as a theme exhibition.
